direction.raw_text: . DAY It's a small church and a small congregation, but it's full. There's a CHOIR of mostly SENIOR CITIZENS arrayed in the back. TWO CLOSED CASKETS are laid out in front of the MINISTER, a fiftyish woman with thick glasses and salt-and- pepper hair, who is giving a eulogy MOS. Among the mourners in the second row sit Terry and Sammy, both redeyed, and uncomfortable in their dress-up clothes. Their Aunt Ruth, a pinch-faced woman in her forties, sits next to them. Sammy and Terry are holding hands tightly. Terry wipes his eyes with his free hand. The Minister addresses her remarks to the children. Sammy is hanging on the Minister's every word; Terry is shifting his eyes and his seat as if it will kill him to sit still another minute.

direction.raw_text: . SIXTEEN YEARS LATER. DAY On the beautiful hill overlooking the beautiful windy green country, SAMMY, twenty-seven years old now, puts flowers on her parents' graves with quick, practiced movements. She is a nice-looking young woman of a neat appearance, saved from primness by an elusive, pleasantly flustered quality. An unsuccessfully neat person. She is dressed in office clothes -- white blouse, dark skirt, high heels, light raincoat over everything. She picks out a couple of weeds and then bows her head and closes her eyes.

direction.raw_text: . DAY Scottsville is a small town. Main Street. Run-down old stores next to a new bank, a couple of chain stores, a few restaurants of varying ambitions. Civil War statue. World War I statue. World War II statue. Residential streets wandering away from Main Street up and down hills. You know there's a minimall somewhere nearby. A fair amount of activity during the daytime.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, I haven't been -- SAMMY I got a postcard from you from Alaska...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I was up there for a while...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But that was in the Fall, Terry...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I know I've been out of touch...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was a little worried. (Pause) I mean -- TERRY Oh, I been a lotta different places... Um... I went down to Florida for a while... I was doing some work in Orlando... I've been all over the place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... I just wish you would have let me know you were OK...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. I didn't realize it'd been so long...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Beaming again) Are you gonna stay in town for a while?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't know... I got all these things I gotta do back in Worcester...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Yeah, so I'm probably not gonna be able to stay more than a day or so...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh... Well... That's all right...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I'm kind of trying to keep to a schedule of sorts. It's a long and worthy story but I won't trouble you with it right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you expecting someone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who would I be expecting here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You just keep looking around, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I was just wondering if we could get some more refreshments, actually.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've actually got to confess to you, Sammy... that the reason you may not have heard from me for a little while is that I've been kind of unable to write... on account of the fact that I was in jail for a little while.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I did a little time, I guess, in Florida. For, uh, just for bullshit...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was just bullshit...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't do anything. Does it occur to you that maybe I was wronged?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, could I please -- SAMMY Oh my God! -- TERRY Would you please let me -- SAMMY -- What happened?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got into a fight in a bar down in Florida. Which I was not the one who instigated it, at all. But they worked up all this bullshit against me and they threw me in the pen for three months. I didn't write you because I didn't want you to get all upset about it. I just figured you'd figure I was on the road for a little while. I know it was stupid and I'm sorry. I really didn't mean to make you worry. But you know what? I can't run around all the time doin' stuff or not doin' stuff because it's gonna make you worry! Because then I come back here, and I tell you about my fuckin'... traumas, and I get this wounded little "I've Let You Down" bullshit, over and over again, and it really just -- cramps me! Like I just want to get out from under it!... And here I am back in this fuckin' hole explaining myself to you again!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you please stop cursing at me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, I realize I'm in no position to, uh, basically say anything, ever -- But it's not like I'm down there in some redneck bar in Florida having an argument with some stripper's boyfriend and I suddenly think, "Hey! Maybe this'd be a good time to really stick it to Sammy and get myself locked up for a few months."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me too, man. I mean "welcome home."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey -- You don't write me for six months, I have no idea where you are -- TERRY I'm sorry -- SAMMY -- I don't know if you're alive or dead -- TERRY I'm sorry -- SAMMY -- and then you show up out of nowhere and tell me you were in jail?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, I'm sorry, I'm sorry, Sammy, I'm really sorry...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sammy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Um... I'm in the midst of a slight predicament...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you need? Money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Um... Yeah... I'm broke. I gotta get back to Worcester tomorrow. I got this girl there, and she's kind of in a bad situation...? I just need to borrow some money. Whatever you can spare. (Pause) I'll pay you back... I'll pay you back, man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I really wish Mom was here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So do I, man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody knows what to do with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know how they feel, man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Terry? Can I ask you something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (With some difficulty) Well -- I mean, do you ever go to church anymore?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Sammy, can we not talk about that shit?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Um -- No, Sammy. I don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you tell me why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Um, yeah. Because I think it's ridiculous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- can you tell me without like, denigrating what I believe in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because I think it's primitive, OK? I think it's a fairy tale.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- I mean, have you ever considered that maybe that's part of what's making things so difficult for you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That you've lost hold of -- well, not just your religious feeling, but lost hold of any kind of anchor, any kind of trust in anything... I mean no wonder you drift around so much. What could ever stop you? How would you ever know if you had found the right thing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, uh, I'm not really looking for anything, man. I'm just, like, trying to get on with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here we go...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: and TERRY Thank you. The WAITRESS leaves. Silence. Terry picks at his salad. Sammy doesn't touch hers. She watches him miserably.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Terry watches while Sammy inserts her card in the ATM and punches in her code. Terry waits. She punches in $300. The machine grinds out her cash. She gives him the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes her card back and puts it back in her wallet.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Sammy... I'm really gonna pay this back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Sammy and Terry get in the car. Sammy isn't saying anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She puts on her glasses and her seat belt. She won't look at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stops. Terry is now totally contrite.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where we going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To pick up Rudy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... do you not even want me to visit now? 'Cause I can catch the bus at five o'clock if that's what you want.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, of course I want you to visit, you idiot! I've been looking forward to seeing you more than anything! I've been telling everyone I know that you were coming home! I cleaned the whole fucking house so it would look nice for you! I thought you were gonna stay for at least a few days! It didn't occur to me that you were just broke again. I wish you would have just sent me an invoice!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Terry sits in the tub. Water drips from the faucet. He is staring blankly up at the pristine blue-and-white tiled wall and the neatly folded matching towels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LATER Sammy and Rudy are in the living room. Rudy is playing with a Game Boy type game. In the b.g., TERRY is dialing the PHONE. He looks clean and shaved, his hair is neatly combed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: CLICK. He is hung up on. He slowly HANGS UP. Sammy notices that something's wrong. He looks at her from across the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Into phone) Hi, is that Malcolm?... Hi, this is Terry Prescott?... I been trying to get ahold of Sheila and there's no answer, and I was just wondering if she -- She what?...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Into phone) When?... Well -- Is she all right?... Well, could I talk to her?... Well, could you give her a message that I --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That girl I'm with tried to kill herself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She tried to kill herself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Terry is sitting on the bed, addressing an envelope to SHEILA. He puts the $300 in the ENVELOPE and seals it. He sees Sammy standing in the doorway. He starts to unlace his boots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sammy comes into the room and sits next to him. He is very busy with his laces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts crying. Sammy pats him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you have everything you need?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you going to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Send the money I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you should stay home for a little while, Terry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, maybe that'd be a good idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY A bright, clear, blue-skied Sunday morning in Scottsville. Inside the little white church they're singing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY People are filing out of the church. We also see a couple of the bank employees, including BRIAN and his very pretty six months' PREGNANT wife, NANCY. We find SAMMY and RUDY. Sammy is chatting to some neighbors. Rudy is bored out of his mind, waiting for her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Terry is lying on the sofa, smoking, with his feet up and boots on, watching Sunday morning TV. On the coffee table are his dirty ashtray, dirty bowl and spoon, Rice Krispies box and a milk carton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Crickets buzz loudly outside the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Sammy, in her bathrobe, comes down the stairs into the living room. Terry is on the sofa playing with Rudy's Game Boy. He barely looks up when she speaks to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry tries to smile at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes back to his game. She hesitates, then heads back up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to bed. Do you have everything you need?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Terry, I'm really glad you're home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, me too, Sammy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Sammy, Terry and Rudy sit at the kitchen table. Sammy is dressed for work. Rudy is dressed for school. Terry is also fully dressed, drinking the last dregs of a mug of coffee. He is tired, but listening to Sammy very carefully, as if receiving difficult and critical instructions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry glances at Rudy, then back at Sammy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . So we'll drop Rudy off at the bus, then all you have to do is drop me off at the bank, and just pick Rudy up at 3:30 in front of town hall, and drive him over to Carol's house. And that's it. She's on Harvey Lane, right past where the Dewitts used to live.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rudy knows where she lives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Sammy walks past MABEL'S DESK, carrying a big stack of files. She drops three of them on the desk. MABEL is typing away at her PC. The colors are a garish PURPLE background with GREEN letters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sammy proceeds down the hall and into -- INT. BRIAN'S OFFICE. DAY Brian is at his desk, busy working between stacks of papers. She knocks on the open door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brian hesitates, shrugs and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sammy looks at him with a blank smile.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: God, Mabel, don't those colors hurt your eyes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no, they keep me fresh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah! (Looks up) Hi, Sammy. What can I do for you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Um, Brian? Did you want us to turn this time sheet in at the end of the day, or do you want it at the end of the week...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yeah, end of the day'll be fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seems like an awful lot of extra paperwork...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I like paperwork.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . A MOMENT LATER Sammy sits down at her desk and notices the time: 3:30. She reaches for the phone, then decides not to call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY The CLOCK on the front of the TOWN HALL reads 3:31. The SCHOOL BUS pulls up across from the town hall and disgorges a handful of kids. Rudy comes out with his knapsack, looking around...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: RUDY: Terry, across the street, sits on the hood of Sammy's car, smoking. Rudy walks over to him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You showed up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Terry and Rudy drive in silence. Terry glances at Rudy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rudy puts on his seat belt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They drive in silence for a moment. Terry glances down at Rudy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Put on your seat belt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It pushes on my neck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It pushes on my neck. It's uncomfortable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, when somebody slams into us and you go sailin' through the windshield, that's liable to be uncomfortable too. So put on your seat belt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mom's parents died in a car accident.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. They're my parents too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They are?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, yeah. Your mom is my sister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So that means we have the same parents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Sammy, laden with files, plops down at her desk as Mabel is passing by. Mabel puts a phone message down in front of her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Um -- Carol just called. She said Terry and Rudy never showed up at her house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've got to be kidding me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Brian, talking to an employee, sees Sammy, across the bank, hurrying out the employees' exit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sammy doesn't hear and exits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Sammy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Terry and Rudy are banging nails with RAY, a young guy Terry's age. Terry, hammering with swift, accurate blows, glances up and watches Rudy for a second. Rudy is hammering away with no great skill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves Rudy's hand down toward the end of the handle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With two swift strokes he drives the nail flush into the wood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry looks at him unsympathetically for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes back to work. Rudy resumes hammering. After a moment he switches his grip and starts hammering Terry's way. Terry looks up and watches him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey. Look.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You hold it further down, you're gonna get a lot more power. You should be able to put that nail down with two or three hits. Look:
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Try it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not the way I hold it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, the way you hold it is wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why can't I just do it my own way?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Shrugs) You can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . A MOMENT LATER Sammy pulls up, fast, and gets out of the car. Hearing the hammering from the backyard, she walks quickly around the side of the house and stops short when she sees Rudy hammering happily away with Terry and Ray. She watches them working, unobserved, with mixed annoyance and relief, and finally with quiet pleasure, because it's a very cheerful sight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Half the staff has gone home. Sammy, in her coat, picks a NOTE up off her CHAIR. It reads:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .S.A.P!!! -- BRIAN" INT. BRIAN'S OFFICE. A MOMENT LATER Sammy stands in front of Brian's desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sammy closes the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Brian? Did you want to see me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. I was kind of wondering what happened to you today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- Didn't Mabel -- I had a false alarm about my son...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I kind of thought you were gonna work that out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I did work it out -- more or less -- BRIAN Then why're you running outta here in the middle of the day without a word of explanation to me, Sammy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Brian, don't yell at me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm -- I'm not yelling. I'm just gettin' a little frustrated here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well Brian:
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, could you close the door please?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Sammy, Terry and Rudy sit at dinner. The atmosphere is lively and cheerful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rudy is amazed. Terry looks at him like, "Told you so."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...And Eddy Dwyer lives in Buffalo, with his wife and two sons, if you can believe it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That is depressing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He just never struck me as the marrying type, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are you talking about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wild kids we used to know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Were you a wild kid?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not compared to your Mom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't believe me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ask her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mom, were you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No comment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Sammy is asleep in bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Rudy is asleep in bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Terry sits at the bar, drinking beer. There are a few locals in the place, but it's pretty dead. He looks around; his energy is too restless for the near-empty bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT The DOOR OPENS, and TERRY COMES IN, smoking a cigarette. He's plastered. He looks around the room. Looks at Rudy's toys. Picks up some superhero comics and sits on Rudy's bed. Then he spies Rudy's COMPOSITION BOOK, picks it up and starts reading it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry looks up. Rudy is half-sitting up in bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rudy is very relieved. Terry keeps reading. Rudy watches him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry lies on his back and smokes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.C.) What are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- Just readin' some of your compositions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why are you smoking?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Um... Because it's bad. Don't ever do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know this used to be my room?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah... (Pause) Do you want it back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you fight in Vietnam?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I wasn't even born yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Were you ever in the army?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My father was in the army.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. Unfortunately he didn't fight in Vietnam either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Were you friends with him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not really. We had some friends in common, I guess... I didn't like him very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, he wasn't very likable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do you say that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. He was always -- He always had to be better than you at everything. You know. Like if you were all playing basketball or something, everybody's havin' like a friendly game and he's like ready to kill somebody if his team didn't win. Or like if you told like a joke or a story, he always had to tell a better one? Kinda gets annoying after a while. Plus it was pretty scummy how he split on your mom and you... He was a prick. Probably still a prick. Fortunately for you though, your mom is like, the greatest. So you had some bad luck and you had some good luck. (Pause) You mind if I ask you a personal question?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you like it here? I mean, in Scottsville?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. My friends are here... I like the scenery... I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, I know, but it's so... There's nothing to do here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes there is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No there isn't, man! It's narrow. It's dull. It's a dull, narrow town full of dull, narrow people who don't know anything except... what things are like right around here. They have no perspective whatsoever. No scope. They might as well be living in the nineteenth century because they have no idea what's going on, and if you try to tell 'em that, they wanna fuckin' kill you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you talking about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a good kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MORNING There's a NOTE on Sammy's chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sammy, just arrived at work and still in her coat, looks down at the note.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Sammy listens to Brian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sammy looks at him blankly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. This doesn't apply to you directly, Sammy, but I've noticed that some of the employees have their PC monitors set with all kinds of crazy colors... Purple and polka dots or what have you. And it's not a big deal, but really, this is a bank. You know? It's not really appropriate. So I'm just asking that people stick to a more quote unquote normal range of colors in future...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like I say, it doesn't really apply to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, my computer palette's pretty conservative.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Mabel is typing angrily at a GRAY SCREEN with BLACK LETTERS. Sammy walks by. Mabel is so mad she doesn't even look up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Sammy sits agitated for a moment. She makes a decision, picks up the phone and dials.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He passes her the joint. She declines. He puffs away. The water drips off the porch and the crickets chirp. She puts her head on his shoulder. He puts one arm around her and puffs away with the joint in his free hand.

direction.raw_text: Sammy straightens up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They stand apart now. Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They stand there. The rain gutters drip.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So... Bob asked me to marry him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wow. (Pause) Are you going to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. If he'd've asked me this time last year I would have probably said yes. But the minute he said it, I don't know, I felt like somebody was trying to strangle me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... bad sign.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. (Pause) Plus, Terry... (Whispers) I fucked my boss...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know! And his wife is six months pregnant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus Christ, Sammy...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Terry, I'm sorry I got so mad before. I just don't want him, you know -- terrified of "telling," if there's -- TERRY Uh, well, that's not really his problem, Sammy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh really? What's his problem?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His problem is that he's like totally sheltered because you treat him like he's three, instead of eight, so that's how he behaves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yeah? And how do you think he should behave?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think he shouldn't have to run and tell his Mommy every time he does something she might not like, for one thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh huh. And what do you -- TERRY (On "and") I mean I took him to play pool! It was a little clandestine thing we did for fun! It wasn't like a big secret, I mean who cares? I was actually trying to be nice to him. But he's so freaked out that he disobeyed your orders that he has to fuckin' squeal on me and I have to listen to your fuckin' shit all day when I didn't even fuckin' do anything!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First of all, he didn't tell me anything: Darryl did. OK? Second of all, I don't really give a shit if you took him to play pool: I was mad at you because you left him standing at the bus stop in the rain. But no, I don't want you telling him not to squeal, because I don't want him put in that position!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Losing ground) Well... that... is a perfect example of what I'm talking about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are in idiot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Darryl told you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MORNING Sammy, coat on, arrives at her desk and puts her purse down. There's a NOTE on her CHAIR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A MOMENT LATER TRACKING SAMMY, coat off, carrying a stack of folders, as she walks from her desk, around the corner, down the hall, past a couple of employees and to BRIAN'S OPEN DOOR. She taps on it. Brian is at his desk.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, good morning. Could you get the door?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Sammy shuts the door. MABEL and DORIS, standing near the door, look at each other: i.e., Sammy's in trouble again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Sammy stands by the closed door. Brian comes out around his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brian kisses her. She drops her folders and they make out against the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Listen -- I just --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : The employees click away at their PCs. Mabel exchanges a quiet word with Chuck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Brian has Sammy pressed against the wall with her skirt hiked up and is trying to get both of their underwear out of the way. It's not so easy in their office clothes. Sammy tears away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Brian, that's enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: falls back, breathless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lunges at her again. They kiss some more.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . Sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . A MOMENT LATER: Sammy comes out of the office, more or less composed, carrying her folders. She heads down the hall past the other employees, including Mabel, and surreptitiously readjusts her scrunched-up underwear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Sammy and Bob sit at lunch. Sammy is picking at her food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're awfully quiet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Um... Have you thought at all about what I said?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course I've been thinking about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So... Any decisions? Or -- do you still want to think about it some more...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- I mean -- I don't know, Bob. I mean, we haven't exactly been going steady the last few months, if you know what I mean -- BOB Yeah, no, I know -- SAMMY -- and then we see each other twice and you suddenly say you want to get married? I mean...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you're right, you're right -- SAMMY What are you talking about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know... I... Maybe this is... Last year I sort of thought you were possibly interested in that... idea... but I was the one who, you know, wasn't "ready" at that point -- So that's why I thought things kind of slowed down with us...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't make me feel bad for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Bristling) I don't want you to feel bad for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Sammy, Terry and Rudy are all watching TV. Sammy and Rudy are in pajamas. Nobody's happy and nobody's talking. The PHONE RINGS. Sammy goes to it and picks up, surprised because of the hour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sammy turns away and lowers her voice so Terry and Rudy won't overhear her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Into phone) Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (On phone) It's Brian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Brian. Where are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SIMULTANEOUS Brian is on the pay phone outside a gas station.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm buying milk. I just thought I'd say hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Sammy doesn't say anything.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I know it's probably too late, but is there any way you can come out for a little while?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Brian, I think you're going crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know I am. Can you meet me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Um, OK.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT SAMMY comes down the stairs, fully dressed, into the living room, where Terry and Rudy are still watching TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry gives Sammy a look like, "You've got to be kidding." Sammy tries to shush him with a conspiratorial look back. She goes out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Um -- I have to go out for a minute. Do you want anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, where are you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just have to go out for a little while.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just have to go to Mabel's house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what, Rudy? It's personal. This is a personal matter that has to do with Mabel. I just have to go see her for a little while.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Terry and Rudy sit in front of the TV, alone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Listen. Listen. I'm sorry I said you squealed on me. I was totally out of line, and I really owe you an apology. (Pause) Did you hear what I said?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Staring at the TV) I don't care.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Sammy drives, listening to music. She shakes her head at herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Sammy's car and Brian's car are parked side by side outside a roadside motel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT In the motel room, Sammy and Brian, half-clothed, make love rather hurriedly on top of the unmade creaky bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Outside the motel, Sammy and Brian get into their respective cars and start their motors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Sammy drives in the other direction. She breaks into a smile, and then she laughs. Then she stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Sammy lies awake plagued by guilty feelings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Sammy heads toward the little white church building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY RON the MINISTER and Sammy drink coffee in silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Gently) What's on your mind, Sammy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, a lot. But principally... I was just wondering if you had an opinion. If you know someone, in your family, or just someone you really care about, and they just can't seem to get ahold of themselves...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The SUN SHINES on Main Street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Rudy watches wide-eyed as Terry places on the sales counter two rods and reels, a bunch of lures, two fishing hats, a box of swivels, a knife and a fish scaler.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You know who this is for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right, my little friend. (To the saleslady) Hello. We're going fishing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Sammy, Terry and Rudy are all putting away the groceries. Everybody seems to be getting along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: O.C., the DOORBELL RINGS. Sammy starts to move toward the door, but Terry is closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sammy watches him go.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I got a new rod and reel, five lures, I got a hat, I got a knife and I got a fish scaler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's great, honey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll get it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Terry opens the door. It's Ron, the minister, in his civvies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Rudy is playing basketball by himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Terry, Sammy and RON sit in the living room. Sammy and Ron are drinking coffee. Through the window we see occasional glimpses of Rudy playing basketball in the backyard. There is a heavy silence in the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns to Sammy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well... I'm not really sure why you're here, Ron. I mean, I realize I haven't exactly been a model citizen since I got here, but compared to how things have been goin' for me lately, I thought I was doing pretty well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I also find it kind of discouraging that you seem to think I need some kind of spiritual counseling or what have you, so much so that you're willing to disregard the fact that I don't believe in any of this stuff at all -- SAMMY Well... I didn't mean to discourage you -- TERRY I mean it's really kind of insulting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I say something here? (Pause) Sammy asked me to come and talk to you, because it's her opinion that you're not gonna find what you're looking for the way you're looking for it -- TERRY How would she know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I'm really not here to try to get you to do anything, or to believe anything. And I'll tell you the same thing I told her, which is that as far as I'm concerned the only way she can help you is by her example -- by trying to be a model for you, by the way she lives her life...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that doesn't mean she's supposed to be a saint, either, if that's what you're smiling about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't realize I was smiling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, Terry, a lot of people come to see me with all kinds of problems. Drugs, alcohol, marital problems, sexual problems, health problems -- TERRY Great job you got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... I like it. Because even in this little town, I feel like what I do is very connected with the real center of people's lives. I'm not saying I'm always Mr. Effective, but I don't feel like my life is off to the side of what's important. You know? I don't feel my happiness and comfort are based on closing my eyes to trouble within myself or trouble in other people. I don't feel like a negligible little scrap, floating around in some kind of empty void, with no sense of connectedness to anything around me except by virtue of whatever little philosophies I can scrape together on my own...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- RON Can I ask you, Terry: Do you think your life is important?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean -- Like, me personally, my individual life?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... I'm not sure -- What do you mean? It's important to me. I guess. And like, to my, you know, the people who care about me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But do you think it's important?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think it's important in the scheme of things? Not just because it's yours, or because you're somebody's brother. Because I don't really get the impression that you do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't think... I don't particularly think anybody's life has any particular importance besides whatever -- you know -- whatever we arbitrarily give it. Which is fine. I mean we might as well... I think I'm as important as anybody else...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know: A lot of what you're saying has a real appeal to me, Ron. A lot of the stuff they told us when we were kids... But I don't want to believe something or not believe it because I might feel bad. I want to believe it because I think it's true or not... I'd like to think that my life is important... Or that it's connected to something important...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, isn't there any way for you to believe that without calling it God, or religion, or whatever term it is you object to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. I believe that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Sammy, Terry and Rudy are all eating dinner. Terry is drinking a beer. His mood is dark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sammy doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So Sammy, what example will you be setting for us tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Terry, Sammy and Rudy are watching TV. Terry has another beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sammy starts to say something to Terry, stops herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rudy doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What time are we getting up to go fishing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're not going fishing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you should go fishing with Father Ron.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to go fishing with Father Ron.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'm not takin' you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take you, sweetie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Sammy and Terry are in the hallway. Sammy holds a stack of folded sheets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She throws the sheets at him and storms away. Terry walks through the living room and OUT the front door, SLAMMING it behind him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I realize that you're mad at me -- TERRY (Deadpan) I'm not mad at you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: but he didn't do anything to you. And you cannot promise a little boy that you're gonna -- TERRY (On "boy") ...I just, you know, after all that religious conversation, I just realized it's probably not so good for him to be spending so much time with someone like me who doesn't believe his life is important in the scheme of things -- SAMMY Would you please...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm serious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Practically choking) Listen. (Pause) I am sure, if you put your mind to it, you can think of some other way of getting back at me besides this. So would you please just give it some thought, and take him fishing tomorrow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I would, Sammy, I just don't think it'd be good for him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You suck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Sammy sits by the phone in her bathrobe. She picks it up and DIALS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : BRIAN'S LIVING ROOM. NANCY, watching TV on the sofa with Brian, picks up the RINGING PHONE.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Into the phone) Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . She gets up, walks around, sits down again. Picks up the phone and DIALS. It RINGS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : BOB'S KITCHENETTE. Bob, making a sandwich for himself, picks up the phone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Into the phone) Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Pause. She sweeps the TELEPHONE and ANSWERING MACHINE OFF the nightstand. Pause. She calms down and puts them back. The ancient answering machine is CLICKING convulsively. She WHACKS IT and it stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY The congregation is coming out of the church and milling around at the steps. SAMMY, with Rudy at her side, is saying good-bye to some neighbors. She watches pregnant NANCY and BRIAN go down the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SAMMY: Beyond Brian and Nancy, TERRY pulls up at the curb in her car. He rummages around and produces FISHING RODS which he waves, somewhat sheepishly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : At top speed, Rudy runs away from Sammy and the church, toward Terry and the car. Terry and Sammy exchange a look from the distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Services are over. Everyone has gone home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LATER Sammy sits with Ron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ron shrugs: i.e., "not necessarily."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Anyway... I don't know what the church's position is on adultery and fornication these days, but I felt really hypocritical not saying anything to you about it before, so... What is the official position on that stuff these days?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... it's a sin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good: I think it should be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...but we don't tend to focus on that aspect of it, right off the bat -- SAMMY Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- SAMMY I think you should.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- SAMMY Maybe it was better when you came in and they screamed at you for having sex with your married boss, and were really mean to you, and told you what a terrible thing it was. Maybe it'd be better if you told me how I'm endangering my immortal soul, and if I don't quit I'm going to burn in hell. Don't you ever think that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Um... No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it's a lot better than all this "Why do you think you're in this situation" psychological bullshit you hear all the time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... Why do you think you're in this situation?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With which one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I feel sorry for them. (Pause) Isn't that ridiculous?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Terry and Rudy are side by side on a small footbridge over a wide running stream, fishing. The sunlight slants through the canopy of trees; the birds are chattering; it's gorgeous and peaceful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence. The birds sing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I've never been so bored in my life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah... We really shoulda been out here around seven or eight A.M.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What time is it now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two-thirty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was my father a good fisherman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, your father was good at all that stuff. He knew everything about the woods, everything about fishing, everything about hunting and everything about cars. If he wasn't such a pain in the ass he would've been a lot of fun to be around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe he's nicer now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I doubt it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I think he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How would you know? Did you ever meet him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Were you ever curious to meet him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, he doesn't live very far from here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought he lived in Alaska.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- I lived in Alaska. Your dad lives in Auburn. Far as I know. (Pause) We could look him up in the phone book. Wanna try?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But -- I'm sure I don't have to say this, but I'm not kidding, man: Don't -- tell -- your -- mother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY BOB is standing by his kitchenette, extremely nervous. Sammy sits on his sofa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him miserably.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes over to him. He gets up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts his arms around her and kisses her. She responds very warmly. Just as things are heating up, she suddenly remembers something and jolts away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you want to go for a walk, or a drive? It's really nice out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I'm not gonna stay long. Bob, I don't want to get married.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've really thought about it a lot, and if you had asked me last year I'm sure I would have said yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I'm not sure it would have been a good idea then either. I'm going through a really hard time right now and I just think that getting engaged to you or anyone would be just about the stupidest most self-destructive thing I could possibly do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I really think you have to grow up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, how about we fix up my personality some other time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . (Pause) I really hope we can still be friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Quietly sarcastic) Oh, yes, me too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bob... This is so crazy... I mean... I don't even understand why you... I don't even get it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want me to say? Everything you said about me was true, Sammy. I was just a big chickenshit jerk, and now I'm payin' the price.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bob...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- I don't know...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Sammy, I love you. I wish I could say it in a more interesting way. I just -- I love you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- I mean -- I love you too --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I gotta go. I'm sorry -- BOB Where do you have to go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Off the top of her head) I'm supposed to -- I gotta get Mabel back her car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... I don't understand. How are we leaving things?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh God, I don't know. Call me later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Brian sits on the edge of one of the beds watching some daytime Sunday show on the motel TV. There is a knock at the door. He gets up, turns off the TV and opens the door. It's Sammy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- What time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a bus at nine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- Can I -- I'd like to see you before you go. I mean, can I give you a lift? Or do you want to have breakfast or anything? And I think Rudy would really like to say good- bye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah -- I don't know... I mean -- SAMMY Terry, you can't just leave like this. I -- TERRY All right, all right. I'll come by in the morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right -- But just -- We have to be out of the house by eight, so -- I don't want to tell Rudy you're coming unless you really think you can make it -- TERRY Yeah -- No -- I'll be there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MORNING Sammy is clearing the breakfast dishes. Rudy is finishing up his cereal. The clock reads 7:50.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You should get your sneakers on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . A MOMENT LATER Sammy comes out and looks up and down the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A FEW MOMENTS LATER Rudy sits in the living room in his baseball jacket. His knapsack is on the floor beside him. He looks at the CLOCK: 8:06. Sammy comes into the living room and looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They HEAR the PICKUP PULL UP OUTSIDE, O.C. Rudy gets up immediately.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sweetie, I'm sorry, we have to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why can't I miss school one day?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . A MOMENT LATER Terry jumps out of RAY'S PICKUP. Sammy opens the front door and Rudy runs out toward Terry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rudy stops short in front of Terry. Terry looks at Sammy, in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, how's it goin', man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry I'm late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The car stops across the street from the BUS. The LAST KIDS are getting in. SAMMY HONKS for the bus driver, and Sammy, Terry and Rudy all get out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rudy hugs Terry. Terry hugs him back. He is suddenly overcome and presses his lips to the top of Rudy's head. Rudy walks to the BUS and gets on. The bus pulls away. Alone now, Sammy and Terry are not that comfortable. He moves to get back in the car, and she does the same.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So Rudy... If I write you a letter, will you write me back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: well, that's gonna be pretty nice for you, because I write a pretty Goddamn interesting letter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, we'll see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. Well, say good-bye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Sammy and Terry sit on a bench near the bus stop. Terry's backpack is by his side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts crying, and looks down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still looking down, Sammy shakes her head, tears leaking down her cheeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She throws her arms around his neck. He pats her gently.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you need some cash for the bus?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I got a few bucks... Aren't you gonna be late for work?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- Yeah. That's OK. (Pause) Terry, I don't even know where you're going.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, well, I didn't really have a concrete plan yet. I have to go back to Worcester and get my stuff...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, are you gonna try to see that girl?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... Yeah... You know... Thought maybe I'd try to show my face... Let her brother have a crack at me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I don't want anyone to have a crack at you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just kidding. I just thought... Just thought I'd check up on her... (Pause) Anyway, after that, I don't really know. I've been thinking about Alaska a lot. I still got some friends out there. I don't really know. Anyway, I'll write you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, Sammy. Of course I will. You know that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is gonna happen to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing too bad... But I gotta tell you, I know things didn't work out too well this time...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Terry -- TERRY ...but it's always really good to know that wherever I am, whatever stupid shit I'm doing, you're back at my home, rooting for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do root for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Sammy. Everything's gonna be all right... Comparatively... And I'll be back this way...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I feel like I'm never gonna see you again...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course you will, Sammy. You never have to worry about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please don't go till you know where you're going. Please...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do know where I'm going. I'm going to Worcester and I'm gonna try to see that girl. And then depending on what happens there, I thought I'd try to see if there's any work for me out West. And if there is, I'm gonna head out there for the summer and try to make some money. And if there isn't, I'll figure something else out. Maybe I'll stay around the East. I don't know... I really liked it in Alaska. It was really beautiful. You just -- It made me feel good. And before things got so messed up I was doin' pretty well out there. Seriously. But I couldn't stay here long, Sammy: I don't want to live here. But I'm gonna stay in touch. And I'll be back. 'Cause I want to see you and I want to see Rudy. I'll come home for Christmas. How about that? We'll have Christmas together. (Pause) Come on, Sammy. You can trust me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Sammy... Look at me... Look at me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Sammy... Remember when we were kids, remember what we always used to say to each other . . .? (Pause) Remember when we were kids?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course I do...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The DOORS OPEN and Terry comes up the steps and into the bus. Outside, Sammy watches him pay the driver and move through the bus toward his seat. The BUS DOORS CLOSE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUOUS Sammy waves till the BUS DRIVES all the way down MAIN STREET, turns a corner and is gone.
direction.name: direction
